articles.headline: Texas Democrats Flee State to Highlight G.O.P. Voting Restrictions
articles.snippet: The move is an attempt to block Republicans from passing a new voting bill while also applying pressure on Congress to pass legislation at the federal level.
articles.abstract: The move is an attempt to block Republicans from passing a new voting bill while also applying pressure on Congress to pass legislation at the federal level.
articles.lead_paragraph: STERLING, Va. — Texas Democrats fled the state on Monday in a last-ditch effort to prevent the passage of a restrictive new voting law by the Republican-controlled Legislature, heading to Washington to draw national attention to their cause.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Monthly Payments to Families With Children to Begin
articles.snippet: The Biden administration will send up to $300 per child a month to most American families thanks to a temporary increase in the child tax credit that advocates hope to extend.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration will send up to $300 per child a month to most American families thanks to a temporary increase in the child tax credit that advocates hope to extend.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If all goes as planned, the Treasury Department will begin making a series of monthly payments in coming days to families with children, setting a milestone in social policy and intensifying a debate over whether to make the subsidies a permanent part of the American safety net.

articles.headline: Latin America Unrest Forces Biden to Confront Challenges to Democracy Close to Home
articles.snippet: U.S. influence began waning in the region over the past decade, as successive administrations turned toward fighting terrorism in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: U.S. influence began waning in the region over the past decade, as successive administrations turned toward fighting terrorism in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden took office with bold warnings for Russia and China about human rights as he pressed democracies around the world to stand up against autocracy. But this week, he is facing a string of similar challenges in America’s neighborhood.

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Press Pfizer for More Evidence of Need for Booster Shot
articles.snippet: After meeting with company representatives, officials said the decision would depend partly on data on infections in vaccinated people that cause serious disease or hospitalization.
articles.abstract: After meeting with company representatives, officials said the decision would depend partly on data on infections in vaccinated people that cause serious disease or hospitalization.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representatives of Pfizer met privately with senior U.S. scientists and regulators on Monday to press their case for swift authorization of coronavirus booster vaccines, amid growing public confusion about whether they will be needed and pushback from federal health officials who say the extra doses are not necessary now.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: China Called Finance Apps the Best Thing Since the Compass. No Longer.
articles.snippet: Beijing’s tech crackdown could imperil the innovation that brought modern finance to underserved people — but also led to concerns about reckless lending and borrowing.
articles.abstract: Beijing’s tech crackdown could imperil the innovation that brought modern finance to underserved people — but also led to concerns about reckless lending and borrowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus jammed up China’s economy last year, Rao Yong needed cash to tide over his online handicrafts business. But he dreaded the idea of spending long, dull hours at the bank.

articles.headline: Prices Pop Again, and Fed and White House Seek to Ease Inflation Fears
articles.snippet: The Consumer Price Index spiked, climbing 5.4 percent in the year through June as used-car prices picked up rapidly.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Price Index spiked, climbing 5.4 percent in the year through June as used-car prices picked up rapidly.
articles.lead_paragraph: A key measure of inflation spiked in June, climbing at the fastest pace in 13 years as prices for used cars, hotel stays and restaurant meals surged while the economy reopens.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Drought Hits the Southwest, and New Mexico’s Canals Run Dry
articles.snippet: Acequias, the fabled irrigation ditches that are a cornerstone of New Mexican culture, have endured centuries of challenges. Can they survive the Southwest’s megadrought?
articles.abstract: Acequias, the fabled irrigation ditches that are a cornerstone of New Mexican culture, have endured centuries of challenges. Can they survive the Southwest’s megadrought?
articles.lead_paragraph: LEDOUX, N.M. — Nestled in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, the remote village of Ledoux has for more than a century relied on a network of irrigation ditches to water its crops. The outpost’s acequias, as New Mexico’s fabled canals are known, are replenished annually by snowmelt and rains. But with the Southwest locked in an unrelenting drought, they have begun to run dry.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Question Amazon’s Connections on Pentagon Contract
articles.snippet: Newly released emails show particular praise of Amazon among top Defense Department officials during the Trump administration as technology firms competed for a $10 billion award.
articles.abstract: Newly released emails show particular praise of Amazon among top Defense Department officials during the Trump administration as technology firms competed for a $10 billion award.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Defense Department prepares to solicit bids for cloud-computing work that could yield billions of dollars for Amazon, members of Congress are raising new questions about the company’s efforts to win a $10 billion contract during the Trump administration.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Behind the Lordstown Debacle, the Hand of a Wall Street Dealmaker
articles.snippet: A longtime real estate investor and former Goldman Sachs executive decided to take an electric truck company public. Chaos ensued.
articles.abstract: A longtime real estate investor and former Goldman Sachs executive decided to take an electric truck company public. Chaos ensued.
articles.lead_paragraph: The clock was ticking for David Hamamoto.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: Hydrogen Is One Answer to Climate Change. Getting It Is the Hard Part.
articles.snippet: Hydrogen is one of the most plentiful elements in the universe, but producing it in a way that is emission-free is costly. Pioneering companies are working to change that.
articles.abstract: Hydrogen is one of the most plentiful elements in the universe, but producing it in a way that is emission-free is costly. Pioneering companies are working to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHEFFIELD, England — Rachel Smith has lived through green hydrogen’s bumpy journey from scientists’ dream to an industry that may be on the verge of a commercial breakthrough. An engineer, she started out two decades ago working in a converted barn on early devices for making the clean-burning gas.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Yellen Makes Case for Ireland to Join Global Tax Deal
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary was in Europe to gather support for the tax plan, an agreement that gained the support of the Group of 20 nations on Saturday.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary was in Europe to gather support for the tax plan, an agreement that gained the support of the Group of 20 nations on Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The United States is hopeful that Ireland will drop its resistance to joining the global tax agreement that it is brokering, as Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen made the case to her Irish counterpart this week that it is in its economic interests to join the deal.

articles.headline: ‘Have you no shame?’ Biden frames voting rights as a moral reckoning.
articles.snippet: The president tried to reinvigorate the fight for voting rights, but he made no mention of rolling back the filibuster, which some see as the only way to beat back Republican-led efforts to restrict ballot access.
articles.abstract: The president tried to reinvigorate the fight for voting rights, but he made no mention of rolling back the filibuster, which some see as the only way to beat back Republican-led efforts to restrict ballot access.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Tuesday that the fight against restrictive voting laws was the “most significant test of our democracy since the Civil War” and called Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election “a big lie.”
